keyTakeAways: At least 44 people have died due to flooding and landslides in central and southeastern Mexico, with Mexico's El Universal reporting a higher toll of 48.

The flooding was caused by heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which impacted central and southeastern states including Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi.
Floods have killed 18 people in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Dozens of people remain missing, and around 320,000 people have experienced power outages, with at least 16,000 homes damaged.
The Mexican military has been mobilized to assist with rescue operations and aid distribution, with images showing evacuations via life rafts and rescue workers navigating waist-high floodwaters.
This event is linked to Mexico’s unusually heavy rainfall this year, with Mexico City experiencing its rainiest June in over two decades.
The remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond were responsible for the downpours, with Raymond’s remnants expected to hit southern Baja California on the same day.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Severe flooding across central and southeastern Mexico, caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, has resulted in at least 44 deaths and dozens missing. The affected states include Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi, with the highest death tolls in Veracruz and Hidalgo. Around 320,000 people have lost power, and 16,000 homes are damaged. The Mexican government has mobilized the military to conduct evacuations and distribute aid, while Mexico City’s record-breaking rainfall in June 2025 underscores a broader climate vulnerability. The reported death toll has been elevated by El Universal to 48, indicating potential underreporting of the human impact.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
